thread.title: KeyRaider hijacks more than 225,000 Apple accounts
thread.title_full: KeyRaider hijacks more than 225,000 Apple accounts | Business Spectator

author: David Swan
title: KeyRaider hijacks more than 225,000 Apple accounts
text:
The security credentials for more than 225,000 Apple accounts, including some in Australia, have been stolen by malware known as ‘KeyRaider’ according to a global security firm.
Palo Alto Networks reported that it, in conjunction with Chinese amateur technical team WeipTech, identified 92 samples of the malware family which it says is responsible for the “largest known Apple account theft caused by malware.”
In a lengthy blog post Claid Xiao reported that KeyRaider targets jailbroken iOS devices and is distributed through third-party Cydia repositories in China.
Mr Xiao said it appears this threat may have impacted users from 18 countries including China, France, Russia, Japan, United Kingdom, United States, Canada, Germany, Australia, Israel, Italy, Spain, Singapore, and South Korea.
“The malware hooks system processes through MobileSubstrate, and steals Apple account usernames, passwords and device GUID by intercepting iTunes traffic on the device,” Mr Xiao said.
“KeyRaider steals Apple push notification service certificates and private keys, steals and shares App Store purchasing information, and disables local and remote unlocking functionalities on iPhones and iPads.
“KeyRaider has successfully stolen over 225,000 valid Apple accounts and thousands of certificates, private keys, and purchasing receipts. The malware uploads stolen data to its command and control (C2) server, which itself contains vulnerabilities that expose user information.”
He said Palo Alto Networks notified Apple about KeyRaider on August 26 and provided it with the stolen account information.
It is suspected that user ‘mischa07’ is the culprit — Mr Xiao said some of the tweaks mischa07 uploaded have been downloaded tens of thousands of times.
The malicious apps and tweaks provide functionalities such as game cheating, system tuning and app advertisement stripping.
WeipTech only recovered about half of the stolen accounts “before the attacker fixed the vulnerability,” Xiao wrote.
One victim reported their phone was held for ransom, while the malware has also been used to steal Apple accounts to buy apps.
Palo Alto Networks also said stolen accounts can be used for app promotion, spam and device unlocking, as well as fraud.
“Our primary suggestion for those who want to prevent KeyRaider and similar malware is to never jailbreak your iPhone or iPad if you can avoid it,” Mr Xiao said.
“At this point in time, there aren’t any Cydia repositories that perform strict security checks on apps or tweaks uploaded to them. Use all Cydia repositories at your own risk.”
Apple has been contacted for comment.
This article was first published in The Australian Business Review.
